unique_users: Consultorio de Alergia e Inmunología - Dr. Juan Carlos Ivancevich

citation.abstract: Delayed maturation of the immune system has been proposed to be a risk factor for development of allergy, but B cell maturation in relation to allergic disease has not been examined. B cells lose CD5 and acquire CD27 during maturation from immature via mature/naive to Ig-secreting cells and memory cells. We sought to investigate B cell maturation in relation to development of allergic disease and sensitization in the FARMFLORA birth cohort including 65 Swedish children. Total B cell numbers, proportions of CD5(+) and CD27(+) B cells, and levels of IgM, IgG, IgA, and IgE were measured in blood on repeated occasions from birth to 36 mo of age, and related to allergic disease and sensitization at 18 and 36 mo of age with multivariate discriminant analysis. We also compared the expression of CD24 and CD38 within CD5(+) and CD5(neg) B cells in children and in adults. We found that infants with a high proportion of CD5(+) B cells at birth and at 1 mo of age had an increased risk for having allergic disease at 18 and 36 mo of life. Further, the proportions of CD5(+) B cells at 1 mo of age were inversely correlated with total IgG levels at 18 and 36 mo of age. The majority of the CD5(+) B cells were of a CD24(hi/+)CD38(hi/+) immature/naive phenotype at birth (97%), 7 y of age (95%), and in adults (86%). These results suggest that development of allergic disease is preceded by an immaturity in neonatal B cell phenotype.
citation.title: High Proportion of CD5+ B Cells in Infants Predicts Development of Allergic Disease

news.title: - Gravide bør dra på bondegård for å piffe opp immunsystemet
news.summary: Barn som bor på gård har langt lavere risiko for å få allergi enn andre barn. Nå vet forskerne mer om hvorfor.

news.title: Children on dairy farms less likely to develop allergies
news.summary: ( University of Gothenburg ) Children who live on farms that produce milk run one-tenth the risk of developing allergies as other rural children. According to researchers at Sahlgrenska Academy, pregnant women may benefit from spending time on dairy farms

news.title: Children on Milk Farms Have Lesser Allergies: Study
news.summary: Children that grow up in milk farms are 90 percent less likely to develop allergies than rural children, a new study finds.

news.title: Animal fur in a crib could prevent allergies and asthma: study
news.summary: Sleeping on animal fur shortly after birth could protect against allergies and asthma, according to German researchers who presented a large-scale, 16-year cohort study at the European Respiratory Society (ERS) International Congress in Munich Monday.

news.title: Children Growing Up on Dairy Farms Have Stronger Immunity Against Allergies
